awd_abstract_narration:
This research into the mathematics of deformation and flow of materials is motivated by applications to subsurface flows of fluids such as groundwater, oil and gas, avalanche dynamics, including the processing of granular materials in tumblers and chutes, the motion of microscopic fluid droplets, and the role of shock waves in the propagation of signals, for example in optical fibers. The mathematics linking these applications concerns the modeling of continuous processes with nonlinear equations, and the study of wave-like solutions of the equations. Recent experiments and new models have opened up opportunities for fresh insights into these complex systems. The research project will include graduate student training in mathematics and physics, with an emphasis on clear presentation of results at scientific conferences. 

This research project on nonlinear models of continuum mechanics focuses on four areas where recent developments provide opportunities for progress. The investigation of dispersive and dissipative shock waves will take place in the context of  models of magnetization and porous media flow. New models of  two phase flow possess singular  nonlinearities that stimulate innovations in analysis and numerical simulation. The  study  of  contact lines of droplets on soft elastic substrates involves the formulation of models for asymmetric drops that can be solved by the method of transforms and dual integral equations. A conjectured mechanism for the motion and control of  microscopic droplets is to induce spatial variations in the elastic modulus of the substrate, thereby providing a driving force on the droplet.  Granular flow models, specifically with poly-disperse grain sizes, will be analyzed using the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations. The equations will incorporate recent descriptions of stress distribution in granular materials, coupled to an established dynamic mechanism that quantifies how grains of different sizes accumulate in distinct layers.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, research focused on four major areas of interest in the modeling of fluids and solids.

It was shown that new equations that describe the dynamic flow of granular materials, such as in avalanches and in the processing of industrial materials, are well-behaved. By contrast, earlier models suffered from a property known as ill-posedness, in which small perturbations to a steady flow create immediate unphysical behavior. In the area of dispersive waves, new understanding arose from analysis of equations that have structural properties not addressed previously.  Applications of the analysis appear in water waves, and in recent models of magma flow; the magma model also represents the flow of a light viscous fluid thread within a heavier fluid. An exciting aspect is that the theoretical results in the latter application have been observed with experiments conducted by collaborators within this project.

The other areas, in the flow of viscous liquids in porous media (subsurface soil, rock), and in the shape and motion of droplets, have been the subject of student research. Results on carbon sequestration (the long-term storage of liquid carbon dioxide) depend on a mathematical understanding of how droplets are deposited in a brine aquifer deep underground, as a plume of injected carbon dioxide migrates against an impervious rock cap. A new class of model of porous media flow depends on ideas from materials science and phase transitions (the change from liquid water to gaseous steam would be an example). The mathematics is challenging, and was aided by experimenting with numerical simulations to test ideas.

Finally, the behavior of droplets on flexible foundations, such as a stiff gel, has relevance in biomechanics. The mathematics depends on modeling the influence of surface tension at the various interfaces between materials, for example between the liquid droplet and the foundation, but also at the contact line, where droplet, foundation and air meet.  There, surface tension forces are in balance, and provide stress on the foundation that distorts the surface, thereby influencing the shape and motion of the droplet. The analysis depends on clever use of mathematical transforms to reduce the problem so that reliable numerical simulation can be applied. Physical experiments are being pursued in conjunction with the student's theoretical research under a separate NSF project.

Overall, the mathematical results of  this project show the potential of mathematical discovery to uncover significant physical behavior described by carefully formulated equations, while introducing innovations in mathematical techniques and analysis and providing research experience for students.
